Etc. you can do this with an online generator like cleverbot or eliza, but you'll get better results if you write your own. it's not that hard! step 2: get real so now we have our bot. we've programmed it to be as human-like as possible. but how can we know for sure? the best way is to test it out on real humans . you could try posting it in a forum somewhere and see what happens, but i'd recommend trying something simpler. here are some suggestions:

Talk to yourself. this is the simplest approach. if you're talking to yourself then there's no risk of offending anyone, and you can just talk about whatever you want. just don't let people walk in on you mid-conversation.

Chat with someone who knows nothing about ai. ask them questions about your program. for example, "how does my robot decide which words to use?" if they ask you why your robot would say certain things, answer honestly. then they'll tell you what they think is going on.
Chat with someone who knows a lot about ai. tell them you're testing out a new kind of turing test. ask them what they think of your robot. they might give you useful feedback.
Chat with someone who knows a lot about programming. explain to them how your code works. if they suggest changes, explain why those changes wouldn't work.
Chat with someone who knows a lot about psychology. ask them how well you're simulating human conversation. if they seem interested, offer to show them your source code.
Chat with someone who knows a lot about both ai and psychology. be careful here. these people are very rare. and even if you find one, you probably shouldn't show them your source code.
Chat with someone who doesn't know anything about any of these things. if you're lucky, they won't notice anything weird. if you're unlucky, they'll realize you're a fraud.
Chat with someone who wants to be convinced that you're a robot. these people are easy to convince. all you need to do is act like a normal person.
